hints.content: Start by understanding what a trailing zero in binary means. A number has a trailing zero if it is even, which means its least significant bit (LSB) is 0.
To check if the bitwise OR of two or more numbers has trailing zeros, you need to consider the binary representations of those numbers. Focus on how the LSB of the OR operation is determined.

Recall that the bitwise OR operation results in a bit being set to 1 if at least one of the corresponding bits in the operands is 1. Therefore, for the OR to have a trailing zero, at least one of the selected numbers must be even.
Consider the implications of selecting numbers from the array. If you can find at least two even numbers, their OR will definitely have a trailing zero. Why is that?
Check the array for the count of even numbers. If there are two or more even numbers, you can immediately return true.
If there are no even numbers, the OR of any combination of numbers will also not have trailing zeros. What would you return in that case?
Think about what happens if there is only one even number in the array. Can you still form a valid selection of two or more numbers that results in a trailing zero?
You can also consider the case where you have a mix of odd and even numbers. The presence of any even number in a selection of two or more numbers is crucial for achieving a trailing zero.
Before implementing your solution, outline the steps: count even numbers, check conditions for returning true or false, and handle edge cases.
Finally, implement the logic to count the even numbers in the array and check if the count is 2 or more. If so, return true; otherwise, return false.

questionNotes: Each number in nums is a positive integer: 1 <= nums[i] <= 100
Return true if two or more elements' bitwise OR has trailing zeros, otherwise return false.
